questions.text:
While flipping through a journal you come across an interesting case of Kartagener’s syndrome. The defect is in specialized cellular appendages in the airways that are involved in expelling the mucus. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding these appendages?
  1. The appendages are present from the nose to the alveoli
  2. Dynein protein drives the movement of this appendage
  3. They contain a microtubule core arranged in a “9+2” pattern
  4. The direction of their movement is constant throughout the airways
  5. They beat in an asynchronous metachronal rhythm of 10-20 times per second
questions.solution:
Kartagener’s syndrome, a type of primary ciliary dyskinesia, affects specialized cellular appendages known as cilia in various parts of the body, including the respiratory tree, where they help in expelling mucus. The true statement regarding cilia is 2 and 3.

Cilia are present in the epithelium of the respiratory passages, starting from the anterior third of the nose and extending to the bronchioles. However, they are absent in the last few generations of the airways, including the alveoli (statement 1). Cilia play a crucial role in clearing the airways as part of the 'mucociliary escalator.' 

On top of them, a mucus layer is present, aiding in trapping foreign particles. These particles are then transported through the synchronized metachronal rhythm of the cilia, which beat at a frequency of 10-20 times per second (statement 5). The direction of their 'power stroke' is always toward the pharynx; that is, the cilia in the lungs beat upward, whereas those in the nose beat downward (statement 4) This continual beating causes the mucus coat to flow slowly toward the pharynx. Subsequently, the mucus and its entrapped particles are either swallowed or coughed to the exterior.

Cilia may be either motile (called secondary cilia) or non-motile (called primary cilia). The motile cilia contain a microtubule core arranged in a “9+2” pattern (nine pairs of microtubules around the circumference of the cilium and one pair of microtubules in the center) (statement 3). Dynein is the molecular motor that drives the movement of the cilium (statement 2).  

Other sites where cilia are present include the fallopian tube, kidney, and inner ear. Nonmotile cilia serve as mechanoreceptors and are involved in determining left-right asymmetry of organs during embryological development, as well as sensing the flow rate of fluid in the nephron of the kidney.

Kartagener’s syndrome or primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to defects in the dynein arm of the cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as the classical triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who is a known case of DVT presents with sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. His ECG shows the characteristic S1Q3T3 changes. A chest X-ray was done which showed the following finding. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the V/Q mismatch in this patient?

V/Q- Ventilation/perfusion ratio.

choices.text: pO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air
V/Q ratio of the alveolus equals to zero
Increased PCO2 in the pulmonary capillary blood

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea in a DVT patient, with ECG showing the characteristic S1Q3T3 changes and chest X-ray showing a hyper-lucent area with decreased vascularity (Westermark sign) are suggestive of pulmonary embolism. Due to the presence of dead space in pulmonary embolism (V/Q = ∞), the pO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air.

In normal individuals, the V/Q ratio is around 0.8. The ventilated alveoli are close to perfused capillaries, which allows for optimal gas exchange. A V/Q mismatch/defect can be induced by ventilation of non-perfused lung regions (dead space), where the V/Q= ∞.

Pulmonary embolism is an example of dead space, in which blood flow to a section of the lung (or even the entire lung) is obstructed. Because no gas exchange occurs in dead space, PO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air. PaO2 is 150 mm Hg and PaCO2 is 0.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, due to right ventricular strain and ischemia:

  • A prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow)
  • Q wave in lead III (red arrow)
  • An inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow)

Other options:

Option A: Increased shunting in the lungs is associated with V/Q= 0(Option C). A right-to-left shunt is the perfusion of non-ventilated lung areas. As there is no ventilation to provide O2 to the blood or remove CO2 from the blood in shunt areas, pulmonary capillary blood from these regions has the same composition as mixed venous blood: PaCO2 is 40mmHg and PaO2 is 40mmHg.

Option D: Increased PCO2 in the pulmonary capillary blood is associated with a low V/Q ratio. Low V/Q areas have some ventilation, as opposed to shunts, which have none. Because ventilation is limited relative to perfusion in these locations, pulmonary capillary blood has a low PO2 and a high PCO2. 

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A baby born at 26 weeks of gestation presented with cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting 3 hours after birth. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry and bilateral homogenous opacification of the lungs on the chest radiograph. This is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of?
questions.solution:
A preterm baby having respiratory distress along with homogenous opacification of the lungs is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of dipalmitoyl lecithin.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, is due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. It is primarily made of phospholipids such as dipalmitoyl lecithin (otherwise known as dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine). The other minor components are phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins, and cholesterol. It is synthesized in type II pneumocytes/granular pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum (shown below).

RDS is commonly seen in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in the surface tension over the alveoli causing the alveoli to collapse easily during expiration. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort into expanding the lungs. Tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring, prominent expiratory grunting, and intercostal and subcostal retractions are some of the common findings seen in this condition. 

Chest X-ray shows features such as reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, and air bronchogram. White-out lungs can be seen on chest X-rays in severe disease.

Management in mild to moderate RDS is with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) where the positive pressure keeps the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation. Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labor.

Other options - 

Option A: Dipalmitoyl serine is a phospholipid present in the cell membrane, which plays a role in apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Dipalmitoyl cephalin or phosphatidylethanolamine is present in the cell membrane. 

Option D: Dipalmitoyl inositol or phosphatidylinositol acts as a precursor for the secondary messenger system. It also helps in cell signaling and membrane trafficking.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her baby to the OPD saying that the baby defecates shortly after every meal. Which of the following GIT hormones amplify this response?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the baby defecating shortly after every meal is a classic description of the gastrocolic reflex. Gastrin amplifies the gastrocolic reflex.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is known as the gastrocolic reflex. This reflex is amplified by the action of gastrin.

GIT reflexes which are mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include:

  • Gastrocolic reflex
  • Enterogastric reflex → signals from the colon and small intestine inhibit stomach motility and secretion
  • Colonoileal reflex → signals from the colon to inhibit the emptying of ileal contents into the colon

GIT reflexes which are mediated by the brain stem and spinal cord include:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex → Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall which are required for defecation.

questions.text: An elderly patient who presented with chest pain is undergoing coronary angiography. When the cardiologist injected the radiocontrast dye into the patient, the patient developed profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. The reflex that is responsible for this scenario is
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for the above scenario is the Bezold Jarisch reflex. 

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

Other options

Option A- C fibre endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia and hypotension. This is called the J reflex.

Option B- Cushing reflex is the increased blood pressure and bradycardia seen in patients with raised intracranial pressure. Increased intracranial pressure compresses the cerebral blood vessels and causes hypercapnia. This stimulates the central chemoreceptors located in the ventrolateral surface of the medulla and causes increased blood pressure. This increase is proportional to the increase in the intracranial pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates baroreceptors and causes bradycardia.

Option C- Brainbridge reflex is the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins and pulmonary circulation.

questions.text:
A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, and dry eyes. Arrange the following in order of their appearance in the cycle occurring in the retina affected in this patient.
  1. Rhodopsin 
  2. Lumirhodopsin
  3. Bathorhodopsin
  4. Metarhodopsin
  5. Scotopsin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, and dry eyes is that of vitamin A deficiency. The cycle occurring in the retina affected in this patient is Wald's visual cycle due to the deficiency of 11-cis retinaldehyde (retinal), a form of vitamin A. The correct sequence of this cycle is 1-3-2-4-5.

1. Rhodopsin 
3. Bathorhodopsin
2. Lumirhodopsin
4. Metarhodopsin
5. Scotopsin

Rhodopsin, the visual pigment of the rod cells in the retina, consists of 11-cis retinal specifically bound to the protein opsin. When rhodopsin is exposed to light, a series of photochemical isomerizations occurs. This results in the bleaching of the visual pigment and release of all-trans-retinal and opsin. This process triggers a nerve impulse that is transmitted by the optic nerve to the brain.

The image given below shows Wald's visual cycle.

questions.text: A patient was admitted for acute diarrhea and vomiting 2 days ago. The doctor on duty assessed that he has recovered from dehydration and ordered discontinuation of the IV fluids. The ward nurse by mistake administered 0.45% NaCl to this patient. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams represents the fluid shift in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient did not need IV fluids but was administered hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl). The Darrow Yannet diagram in image 3 represents the fluid shift in case of hypotonic fluid administration as seen in this patient. 

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either the addition or removal of fluid.

Hypotonic saline leads to the decreased osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. The net result is the decreased osmolarity and increased volume of both the compartments.

Other options:

Image 1- Normal ECF and ICF balance.

Image 2- The addition of isotonic saline to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Image 4- The addition of hypertonic saline to the ECF pulls the fluid from the ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: The pupillary light reflex is being assessed in a child with suspected cranial nerve palsy. Which two cranial nerves are being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 2nd and 3rd cranial nerves are being tested during the pupillary light reflex. The afferent of pupillary light reflex is the 2nd cranial nerve and the efferent is the 3rd cranial nerve.

When light is shone in one eye, the pupils of both eyes constrict. 

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex. 

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First-order neurons (sensory) connect each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. The sensory fibers are carried through the optic nerve. 
  • Second-order neurons (internuncial) connect each pretectal nucleus to bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third-order neurons (preganglionic motor) connect the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. These parasympathetic fibers pass via the oculomotor nerve. 
  • Fourth-order neurons (postganglionic motor) leave the ciliary ganglion and pass into the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae in both eyes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.

Sildenafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction. It inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.

Penile erection is produced by the release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man working in a loud machinery unit came to the OPD complaining of hearing loss for the past 3 months. He also complains of high-pitched tinnitus and is unable to hear in noisy environments. On pure tone audiometry, a downsloping audiogram is seen. Which of the following ions is responsible for the depolarisation of hair cells in the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old man with hearing loss and pure tone audiometry showing a downsloping audiogram is suggestive of noise-induced hearing loss. K+ ion is responsible for depolarising hair cells in the cochlea.

Noise-induced hearing loss is a sensorineural hearing loss and is seen in chronic exposure to loud sounds in occupation. It is caused by irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in the organ of Corti. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

PTA showing noise-induced hearing loss as downsloping audiogram:

The hair cells are located in the following six patches and correspond to the respective signals.

  • Organ of Corti - hearing
  • Utricle - horizontal acceleration
  • Saccule - vertical acceleration
  • Three semicircular canals - rotational acceleration

The hair cell has a resting potential of -60 mV. When all the stereocilia bend towards kinocilium there is an influx of K+ resulting in depolarization. Depolarization in turn opens voltage-gated calcium channels in the hair cell membrane, and the resultant Ca2+ influx causes transmitter release from the basal end of the cell onto the auditory nerve endings. If the movement of the stereocilia is in the opposite direction, it leads to hyperpolarisation.

questions.text: An elderly patient was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and was started on beta-blockers. However, the patient continued to have symptoms despite its use. He was then started on ivabradine. This drug improves the symptoms of angina by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine decreases the automaticity in the sinoatrial node and thus reduces the heart rate improving the symptoms of angina. This reduction in the heart rate decreases the myocardial oxygen demand.

The oxygen requirement of the heart mainly depends on the work done by the heart. This work mainly depends on cardiac output and peripheral resistance. An increase in these parameters will increase the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Important determinants of cardiac output are:

Stroke volume- It is the amount of blood pumped out of the heart during each heartbeat. This stroke volume increases whenever, there is increased venous return to the heart, increased end-diastolic volume (preload), and increased contractility. Contractility further depends on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber and the autonomic innervation.

Heart rate- Increased heart rate increases the cardiac output which in turn increases the oxygen requirement. Heart rate is controlled primarily by the autonomic nerves, with sympathetic stimulation increasing the rate and parasympathetic stimulation decreasing the rate.

Afterload- The tension at which the load is lifted is called afterload. As the afterload increases, the heart has to work more to pump blood to the organs. This in turn results in increased oxygen requirement. It is dependent on the peripheral resistance. 

Drugs used in the management of angina either decrease the work done by the heart or increase the blood flow to the heart.

  • Nitrates- They increase the cGMP and cause vasodilation. It mainly results in an increase in venous capacitance and a decrease in the ventricular preload. They might also increase coronary flow in some areas and variant anginas.
  • Calcium channel blockers- Blocking the calcium channels leads to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and decreased impulses in the conduction system. This leads to decreased peripheral resistance, decreased blood pressure, decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, and decreased oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Beta-blockers- They decrease the oxygen requirement by decreasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. Some drugs like carvedilol and nebivolol also cause vasodilation.

Newer antianginal drugs

  • Ranolazine- It inhibits the late sodium current and reduces the intracellular calcium concentration. It reduces diastolic tension, cardiac contractility, and work.
  • Trimetazidine- inhibits the fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. It decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Ivabradine- decreases the heart rate and decreases oxygen requirement.
  • Fasudil- It is a Rho kinase inhibitor. It is useful in coronary vasospasm.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: Oxytocin is released when the cervix is stretched by the fetal head, leading to uterine contractions. What is the control mechanism in the above reflex?
questions.solution:
The reflex described is the parturition reflex, a positive feedback mechanism (option C). 

A positive feedback mechanism is one in which the stimulus of the mechanism leads to enhancement and further continuation of the mechanism. In the parturition reflex, cervical stretch due to uterine contractions stimulates the release of oxytocin, which further increases the uterine contractions. Thus, there is increased cervical stretch and oxytocin release. A positive feedback loop is established. This continues till the expulsion of the products of conception. 

Other options:

Option A- Negative feedback mechanism is one in which the stimulus of the mechanism leads to inhibition of the mechanism and, thus, a decrease in the stimulus. An example is the baroreceptor reflex for blood pressure regulation. 

Option B- Feed-forward control is a control system in which the body anticipates a response and makes corrective changes without a specific stimulus. An example of this is the cephalic phase of gastric secretion. 

Option D- Adaptive control is a delayed type of negative feedback mechanism. When feed-forward control makes an error, a retrospective feedback mechanism called adaptive control corrects it.

questions.text: A 32-year-old multipara at 40 weeks gestation developed water intoxication and hyponatremia following prolonged intravenous infusion with oxytocin by an inexperienced junior resident. This adverse effect is due to oxytocin's action on which of the following sites?

choices.text: Vasopressin V2 receptors on basal surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V2 receptors on apical surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V1 receptors on basal surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V1 receptors on apical surface of renal tubular cells

questions.solution:
Oxytocin can bind to V2 receptors on the basal surface of renal tubular cells resulting in reduced free water clearance.

This is because oxytocin and vasopressin have structural similarities. Oxytocin can have vasopressin (ADH) like activity at V2 receptors on the basal surface of principal cells that line the distal tubules and medullary collecting tubules of the kidney. The increase in water permeability occurs through the insertion of aquaporin-2 on the apical surface of the principal cells of the kidney which allows water to through the cell down the osmotic gradient created by the hypertonicity of the renal medulla. 

Prolonged intravenous administration of oxytocin at high doses in conjunction with large volumes of hypotonic fluid may cause water intoxication associated with hyponatremia.

To avoid this complication, whenever high doses of oxytocin are administered over a long time:

  • An electrolyte-containing diluent must be used (not dextrose).
  • The volume of infused fluid should be kept low (by infusing oxytocin at a higher concentration).
  • Fluid intake must be restricted, a fluid balance chart should be kept and serum electrolytes should be monitored.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is found to have a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. This toxin blocks acetylcholine release by inhibiting which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the infant having a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control with a history of honey ingestion is suggestive of infant botulism. The botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine by inhibiting synaptobrevin.

Infant botulism is also called floppy baby syndrome. It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months. It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxins. Affected children usually present with paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weakness, altered crying, and loss of head control.

Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxins or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

The image given below shows gram staining of Clostridium botulinum.

Botulinum toxin B cleaves synaptobrevin, a VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein). Botulinum toxins A and E act by cleaving synaptosome-associated protein-25 (SNAP-25), a presynaptic membrane protein needed for the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine to the terminal membrane. The botulinum toxins block the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cause flaccid paralysis. Symptoms can include ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

The image given below shows the site of action of botulinum toxin.

Other options:

Options A and B: Clathrin and Megalin are required for endocytosis.

Option D: Desmin is an intermediate filament. It is present in the sarcomeres in muscle cells.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident. During the examination, the patient was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth. However, he was still able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit.

Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: You evaluate a 60-year-old man who presented with difficulty in forming words. He can make noises and give expressions as if he understood the questions asked. Which of the Brodmann areas is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly man with difficulty in forming words and intact comprehension is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Brodmann area 44 will be affected.

In Broca's aphasia/motor aphasia/non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

Other options:

Option A: Area 4 corresponds to the primary motor area which is responsible for initiating and coordinating motor activities.

Option B: Area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's speech area which is responsible for the interpretation and understanding of verbal and written words. Lesions in this area will result in fluent aphasia in which the person talks with increased fluency with new words but is inappropriate to the context due to lack of interpretation. 

Option C: Area 42 corresponds to the primary auditory area responsible for the reception of various auditory stimuli.

questions.text: A man who was stuck inside a building that caught fire was rescued and brought to the hospital. His oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve was found to be shifted in the same direction as
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient most likely has carbon monoxide poisoning due to smoke inhalation. The O2–Hb dissociation curve shifts to the left due to carboxyhemoglobin. The leftward shift is also seen with methemoglobin, fetal hemoglobin, hypothermia, alkalosis, decreased pCO2, and decreased 2,3- diphosphoglyceric acid (2,3-DPG).

Methemoglobin forms when hemoglobin is oxidized, causing the iron to shift from its normal ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state. When any of the four iron atoms in a hemoglobin molecule are in the ferric state, they can no longer bind oxygen. The presence of ferric iron induces allosteric changes in the hemoglobin structure, resulting in a leftward shift of the oxygen-dissociation curve. This shift increases the affinity of the remaining ferrous iron for oxygen, but it impairs oxygen release to tissues. Consequently, this disruption leads to reduced oxygen delivery and tissue hypoxia. Treatment of methemoglobinemia involves supportive care, cessation of offending drug, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue.

In carbon monoxide poisoning, the affinity of Hb for CO is about 200 times more than that for O2, and hence, the carboxyhemoglobin releases the CO into the blood very slowly. Treatment of CO poisoning consists of ventilation with oxygen since oxygen hastens the dissociation of carboxyhemoglobin. 

The other options such as hyperthermia, chronic anemia, and sulfhemoglobin will shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right.

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The gynecologist collects the cervical mucus and spreads it on the microscope. It shows the following appearance. The patient had her periods 22 days back. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
She is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding this patient is that she has not ovulated. The presence of a fern pattern of cervical mucus on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperm. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern. After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise and this hormone makes the cervical mucus thick. The ferning pattern will no longer be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

Before ovulation, the phase is known as the preovulatory phase or the follicular phase of the cycle. The uterus is undergoing proliferative changes, hence it is also known as the proliferative phase. After ovulation occurs, the corpus luteum secretes estrogen and progesterone and this phase is known as the luteal phase or secretory phase. In this phase, the uterus is vascular, and edematous with coiled glands.

 The tests for ovulation are:

  • The body temperature decreases during ovulation and increases by 1/2 to 1°F. This is due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.
  • Endometrial biopsy- usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 
  • Fern test- The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.
  • Ultrasound- used to monitor the maturation of the Graffian follicle and ovulation.
  • Hormonal studies - Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred and determination of LH surge.

questions.text: After hitting your elbow against the wall, rubbing the affected area seems to relieve the pain. The stimulation of which of the following fibers is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain relief experienced after rubbing the affected area is due to the stimulation of Aβ sensory fibers.

The stimulation of large-type Aβ sensory fibers from peripheral tactile receptors depresses pain signal transmission from the same body area. This occurs due to local lateral inhibition in the spinal cord.

The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents may reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to the nociceptive input from afferent terminals. It explains why rubbing the skin near painful areas offers pain relief, and also explains why the local application of liniments relieves pain.

This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation. It is the principle behind the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief. TENS uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury.

Note:
Pain stimulus is transmitted by Aδ (fast pain) and C fibers (slow pain).

questions.text:
A patient who consumes non-iodized salt presents with weight gain, constipation, hair loss, and fatigue for 3 months. On examination, the finding given below is seen. What is the reason for the presence of this finding?

(TSH - thyroid-stimulating hormone)
questions.solution:
The image shows the diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland known as goiter. A patient who consumes non-iodized salt and has weight gain, constipation, hair loss, and fatigue has hypothyroidism due to iodine deficiency. The reason for the presence of goiter in this condition is elevated plasma TSH levels.

Goitre is the diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. It may be seen in hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and euthyroidism as well. It is caused by the action of excess TSH or substances similar to TSH on the thyroid gland. This is due to the trophic action of TSH on the thyroid gland i.e. it causes hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the follicular cells.

In patients with iodine deficiency, the production of thyroid hormones is impaired and features of hypothyroidism develop. Decreased levels of the thyroid hormones result in increased TSH secretion from the anterior pituitary via negative feedback. TSH stimulates hypertrophy and hyperplasia of follicular cells and the secretion of large amounts of thyroglobulin. Thus, the thyroid gland enlarges. This condition is known as endemic goiter.

Other causes of hypothyroidism resulting in goiter are autoimmune thyroiditis, deiodinase deficiency, and disorders of iodide trapping, peroxidase, or coupling systems. Consumption of food containing goitrogenic substances (eg: turnips, cabbages) also results in goiter.

Other options:

Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is the transient inhibition of the organification of iodide when large doses of iodide are consumed. This results in a decrease in thyroid hormone synthesis.  This effect will not be seen in this patient who consumes non-iodized salt.

Option C: In Grave’s disease, TSH-receptor antibodies are present. They act similar to TSH and stimulate excessive secretion of thyroid hormones. Patients with Grave’s disease present with goiter, weight loss, exophthalmos, tremors, and tachycardia.  

Option D: Mucopolysaccharide deposition is the mechanism of myxedema formation in hypothyroid patients. The deposition results in fluid filtration out of the capillaries and the formation of non-pitting edema.
